subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] on screen representation of senior quikscript
msgSnippet: Tony: The font Jerome, which was the first QS font, had the capability of joining letters together and permitted the use of half-letters.  In actual use,
messageBody:
Tony:

The font Jerome, which was the first QS font, had the capability of joining letters together and permitted the use of half-letters.  In actual use, however, it had some problems, though, and the fonts that came after it were focused more on junior QS.  A new attempt at a senior QS font would be welcome and certainly interesting.  I, for one, would consider using it if you could get it to work well.  It would permit the computer to reproduce the cursive character of QS which I find so interesting.

This is not to say that an artistic, well-designed junior QS font is not needed.  Paul Tremblay is working on just such a new junior font now that will deal with some of the issues the existing junior fonts have had.  I have great hopes for it.

Thanks for your interest, and I would be happy to assist you in any way I can if you decide to work on such a project.

Paige

othermale wrote:

Hi All,

I wonder, does anyone know of an attempt to represent _senior_
quikscript typographically (ie enterable and viewable on a computer)?
I suppose this would be quite a bit more than just a font (eg the
challenge of joining the letter "roar"(aka "roe") and half letter
"zoo" in the abbreviation for Mrs. or the joining of "sis"("see") with
"pipe"("pea" ) ). I was toying with the notion of building an app for
this but if this or something better has already been done by someone...

cheers,
-Tony
